segments.text: Today's interview is with Lester O'Bannon, retired professor of mechanical engineering at Texas A&M University.
Professor O'Bannon, who is 88, retired from A&M in 1964.
Today's date is July 29, 1982.
Let's begin, Professor O'Bannon, by your telling us something about your early years as a boy in Kentucky.
First thing I remember was William McKinley getting shot when he was president.
You were five years old at the time?
I was about five or six years old.
And I remember faintly the fact that the Spanish-American War was on about that time.
When I was just a small child, I can recall seeing a neighbor man
in uniform parading around, showing himself off in his front yard.
And I guess that was my very first impression of the Spanish-American War, because I didn't know anything about what was going on.
You were born in May 1894 in Stanford, Kentucky.
That's right, May 5th.
We had the same birthday.
Stanford, Kentucky.
That's S-T-A-N-F-O-R-D.
I don't know how much you want me to tell.
How long you got to listen?
How long it takes.
Did you live most of all your boyhood years in Stanford, or did you move elsewhere?
I lived there.
My address was there until I graduated from college, and then I moved on from there.
And you graduated from the University of Kentucky at Lexington in what year?
With a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering?
A degree of bachelor of mechanical engineering.
It was not bachelor of science, but just bachelor of mechanical engineering, BME.
That was the custom in those days.
How did you get interested in engineering?
I didn't.
It was just always assumed from the very beginning that I was going to go to college and take engineering.
Why?
I was always told that I was going to take electrical engineering.
My father was an MD.
He was a country doctor, very popular physician in that community.
But his hobby was, I would say, cabinet making and building.
And the closest thing that he could think of to that was engineering.
And I'd fooled around with some electrical equipment while I was still in grade school or early high school.
And everybody assumed that I was going to be an electrical engineer.
And I went to college for that purpose.
But at the University of Kentucky in those days, there was no such thing as an Department of Electrical Engineering.
There was only Department of Mechanical Engineering, in which
electrical engineering courses were taught.
And although a fellow could specialize in electrical engineering, he got his degree in mechanical engineering.
There were other colleges there, such as mining, metallurgy, civil.
But mechanical engineering at that time included electrical engineering.
And I was asked to fill out a form indicating what branch of engineering I wanted to be in.
There was a list of them there.
And among that list was steam engineering.
And I had sort of taken a fancy to one of the professors in the department who taught steam engineering.
And for some reason that I can't explain, I just checked on that form, steam engineering.
And sure enough, after graduating a few weeks, I got a letter from the dean, which was a copy of letter that he had written to the steel company in South Chicago.
They had written to the college asking for recommendations for somebody
be employed in their steam engineering department.
So I had checked steam on this form and here came a request for a steam engineer.
So the dean recommended me.
So it was the first offer I'd had in just two or three weeks after graduation.
So I wrote back and indicated I was interested in the job.
the detail.
But anyhow, I ended up in South Chicago in the steam engineering department of the South Works of the U.S. Steel Corporation, or at that time it was in Illinois.
That was in 1915?
1915, summer of 1915.
At that time it was the Illinois Steel Company, but it was a subsidiary of U.S. Steel.
Just like across the border into Indiana was the Gehry Works, which is a subsidiary of the U.S. Steel.
And there were a couple of other steel corporations there in South Chicago.
So I showed up there, and I could tell a look of disappointment on their face.
If you'd have read this letter of recommendation from my dean concerning me to the steel corporation,
you would have thought that I was about a six and a half foot Irish giant.
Of course, the apostrophe in the name gave them that implication.
And when I walked in there, weighing 120 pounds and six and a half feet tall, you could just see the consternation over the faces of everybody in the office.
And I had on a beautiful pink silk shirt and a bow tie and so forth.
I looked like anything but a steel employee, I'll tell you that.
Anyhow, they had to accept me, and they got me up there for that purpose.
Well, I started in there with the title of steam expert in the steam engineering department.
How long did you stay there?
Until late spring of 1918, when I left them and went into the Army in the First World War.
Were you drafted?
No, I volunteered.
I don't know why I wasn't drafted.
I've often wondered, but I think the reason was that in the first place, I didn't look like a soldier.
I looked more like a high school kid.
I've always said that has been one of my handicaps all my life.
I always looked 10 years younger than I was.
I used to be kidding about that.
I had a sister who would look at a photograph of herself.
And she'd pop.
I would be, oh, 24, 25 years old.
And she says, well, you look like you just graduated from high school.
Well, I've had to put up with that all my life.
Right now, at my age, I get out on the campus here and can't anybody believe that I'm 88 years old.
I don't know what I look like, but according to my friends, I don't look over maybe 75, something like that.
Which has always been a big joke to me.
I've had that to endure all my life.
How long you stayed in the Army, until 1919 or 1920?
I would have had to get in.
I don't believe I would have been drafted because the job I had there was a semi-technical job.
And I've always felt, I'm not sure that this happened, that the draft board has sort of been told, just leave this fellow alone.
We need him, you see.
It was a specialized technical job.
And I was the only one in the whole plant that did that work.
I may be wrong about that.
I used to get on the train at 53rd Street in Chicago and ride to 79th Street, where the office was.
I'd be going in the opposite direction to traffic, because the traffic in those days was from the outside communities towards the Loop downtown.
But I was going the opposite direction.
There wouldn't be over half a dozen people on the train, so I could see everybody.
And I looked, they were all old men.
There wasn't a single young fella on the train.

And I got a little bit self-conscious about it, thinking, well, maybe as young as I was, I was in good physical health and so forth, maybe I should be in the Army instead of riding this train with these old men.
So I just got the notion one day and went down to the draft board.
And I told them, I said, when is your next contingency leaving here for camp?
And they told me, they said, well, I wish you'd put me in that list.
I want to volunteer.
And they did.
So I got on a train there and rode to Rockford, Illinois.
That's where they, in those days, they called it, what did they call it?
name that had went by.
But it's where the rookies were taken in.
And they were disciplined there for a few weeks.
And finally, they were sent to some specific department.
Or rather, what happened, officers from other divisions would come there to the camp.
And these rookies were all lined up.
And they would come by.
interview each fellow.
And their idea was to choose people to go into certain divisions, and infantry, artillery, and so forth.
So this one captain kept quizzing me.
And he learned that I was a college graduate.
And I think that's what convinced him.
He chose me to go with him in the artillery.
And that's what I did.
And the next place I remember was Sparta, Wisconsin, where they had a rifle range.
I don't know if you know where that is or not.
It's near La Crosse, and La Crosse is right on the Mississippi River between Wisconsin and Minnesota.
Sparta, Wisconsin.
And I was definitely in the artillery then, Battery B, 333rd Field Artillery.
And we had rifle practice there.
And we were there five or six weeks.
Then, of course, I don't know what happened, but the whole group then of this Battery, Battery B,
left Sparta and we were put on the train to the east coast.
We went first to camp on Long Island, where we stayed a few days, and then we were put on a boat and shipped to Europe.
When did you reach Europe?
Oh, let's see.
Some summer of
May have been July, August, something like that.
Well, I never did get into action.
What happened was that we were in the heavy field artillery.
in the guns we were to use until we got in France.
We landed in Glasgow, Scotland.

I was with a group of senior citizens here on campus or at one of the hotels not long ago, and there was a little group of people there talking about traveling in England and Scotland, and most of it was about Scotland.
Everybody had been to Edinburgh.
I didn't say a word.
And I didn't have any use of it.
I didn't need to say a word.
Some woman across the table says, have you been to Scotland?
And I said, well, I've been to Glasgow.
And what another word said.
I couldn't tell them that I'd been to Edinburgh, which is what they'd been talking about, but I had been to Glasgow.
I didn't tell them I was there only about five or six hours.
We got off the boat of Glasgow, got on a train, and rode down through England to Southampton, which was on the Channel.
I don't know how much you use this you want to see, I'm just rattling off.
We were there at Southampton for a few hours, and we were
Late that night, or after dark, we were put on a boat just across the channel.

And I was, the next morning we woke up right back where we had been, in Southampton, and we started making inquiries, and somebody who seemed to know what he was talking about, one of the crew, boat crew or somebody,
He says, well, he says, we started for Cherbourg, but we got chased back by U-boats.
Well, that was quite an experience, even though we hadn't experienced it.
So we stayed there all day long.
And the next night, we started across again.
And this time, we made it.
We landed at Cherbourg.
I remember it was the first time we'd taken a bath and had a change of clothing since we left the States.
This was a shower bath, and you had just so many minutes in there, and if you didn't get the soap washed off at the proper time, you had to wipe it off with a towel.
They'd just shut off the water.
That's how scarce it was.
Well, we were there in Cherbourg for maybe overnight or something like that.
Then we were put on a train and we rode south through France to a camp.
Southern France wasn't too far from the Spanish border.
The largest city was Bordeaux, which was on the coast.
And that's where we got our training with the guns.
We were 155 millimeter height Snyder howitzers, which was a shell about six inches in diameter.
We'd never seen one of them before.
We'd never seen the guns.
So before we left the States, I had been made a corporal.
And soon after we got into France, I was made a sergeant.
And I was a sergeant of a gun section, which included about, oh, I'd say 24 men altogether.
Three squads, eight men per squad.
And there were several of those sections in the battery.
So I was one among four, five, or six sergeants.
And of course, above us was the top sergeant.
because you had no responsibility whatsoever.
You got your orders from the officers above, captain, lieutenant, second lieutenant, and then you passed them on to the corporals, and they would pass them on to the men.
That was the system.
So a sergeant didn't have to know anything other than just how to translate a message from the officers to the lower ranks.
That's an exaggeration.
I did know something about it.
As a matter of fact, I knew as much about it as any man in the battery.
You couldn't escape learning it.
How long were you there before you were sent back to the United States?
Well, of course, the armistice came in November the 11th.
We'd had a false alarm about a week ahead of time.
And we all celebrated the armistice.
So when it came on November the 11th, we didn't pay a damn little attention to it.
It just made no impression whatsoever.
It was a letdown, because this false information that had been let out there in the camp where we were a week ahead of time, we'd already done the celebrating.
So the war didn't actually end until November the 11th.
By that time, as far as we'd be concerned, it had been over for a week.
So we loafed there in camp until I believe it was Christmas Day.
Or maybe the day before Christmas, we marched from this camp to Bordeaux.
And on Christmas morning, we got on a boat.
And on New Year's Day, we got off of that boat in New York City.
About seven days coming back, going over it took 14 days.
Do you think that if the U.S. had joined the League of Nations that some of the problems that occurred after World War I might have been avoided?
After World War I?
No.
You don't think the League of Nations would have been any more effective than the U.N.?
No.
The Germans had been defeated.
Tactically, militarily, economically, they were defeated.
But within themselves, they were never defeated, and they were going to start a war sooner or later.
And they did.
Do you think the peace terms that were imposed on the Germans were harsh?
No, no, that didn't happen to them.
They may or may not have been, but it had nothing to do with the Second World War.
Okay, when you were back in the United States in 1919, New Year's Day, what happened?
What did you do to pursue then?
We just waited around for another 30 days until we were discharged.
And then where did you go after you were discharged?
It was late in January when we were discharged.
So I was in the Army altogether, I'd say about ten months, something like that, nine or ten months.
About three months in France, and the rest of the time in this country, either before or after being in the Army.
Where did you go after you were discharged here?
Well, that's a long story.
Well, just ultimately, where did you go?
I had a sister who lived in Elyria, Ohio.
E-L-Y-R-I-A.
It's about 20 miles west of Cleveland.
And her husband was... What do you call him?
He ran the city government down.
What did he call those people in those days?
City manager.
City manager, something like, some title similar to that.
I don't think they sent him city manager, but some other title.
And he knew some businessmen there in Elyria.
Well, I went by Elyria just as a means.
And he was the city manager of Elyria or of Cleveland?
Elyria.
I was on my way home to Kentucky and just went by Elyria to visit my sister.
I had shipped my personal belongings to her when I left Chicago to go into the Army.
I had some books and other things that I had shipped to her.
So I went by there and picked that up and then went on to Kentucky.
But my brother-in-law had his acquaintances there of area businessmen.
He knew the superintendent of the blast furnace department in the National Tube Company, Lorain, Ohio, which was right on the lake.
That was the industrial city for that part of northern Ohio.
Is that Lorain with two R's?
No.
L-O-R-A-I-N-D?
I think so, yeah.
I'm not sure.
where the top personnel lived who worked for the steel company in Elyria.
So I commuted, when I got the job, I commuted from Elyria to Lorain and worked there at the National Tube Company.
And I got that job, as I say, through the fact that my brother-in-law had
acquainted with some of the officers, and they found out that I was looking for a job.
And what really got me the job was that the work that I had done at the South Works plant in South Chicago was the kind of work for which they wanted a man, to hire a man there at Lorraine.
So since I had that experience, it was easy for me to get the job.
months at the most.
I wasn't happy with it.
It was a letdown from what I had done in South Chicago.
In South Chicago, I had charge of certain accounts which included every department in the whole plant.
And Lorraine, with the National Tube Company,
which was a rather narrow line of duty compared to what I'd had in South Chicago, so it didn't fascinate me in the slightest.
Then what did you do after that?
Well, there was a great building boom going on at that time.
See, this is back in 1919.
World War was over, business began to take up, to pick up, and a lot of construction work going on.
And as I said, almost in the beginning, I had grown up in the construction business, you might say, because that had been a hobby of my father, buying and selling houses.
remodeling them and so forth and so on.
Most of the labor he used for that purpose was patients of his who hadn't paid their accounts, so he'd get work out of them.
Well, anyhow, there was a building boom going on there in Elyria, and my brother-in-law sort of encouraged me to get into that.
My father, when he heard about it, sort of gave me some encouragement.
As a matter of fact, he lent me some money to buy a lot there.
And I was going to build on that lot.
In the meantime, before I reached that point, I built a residence for my brother-in-law and another residence I built for one of the men I had known at the steelworks, Lorraine.
And this third house was one which would have belonged to me with the money that the father lent me to buy the lot.
So, it looked as though I was going to be a building contractor.
I went on home on vacation after being in the army.
And
Excuse me, but this story's got to stop someplace.
I can't go on forever.
Well, after, where did you finally?
I went, let me tell you how I got into the education business.
All right, let's just move to that.
On my way home from Larry, Ohio to Stanford, Kentucky, I stopped at Lexington and visited the university where I had graduated.
Yeah.
This was in 1920, where I had graduated five years earlier, and this was the first time I had been back there.
So I went by the campus, and I visited some old professors in the department that I had remembered from five years earlier, and saw some new buildings and so forth, and ended up in the dean's office.
And just like you and I are talking now,
The dean and I started talking about myself.
He wanted to know what I had been doing.
So I didn't take this long, I don't think.
But I told him about my experience at South Chicago with the Steel Corporation and being in the Army and then working for the National Tube Company in Lorain and so forth and so on.
And I about wore him out.
He wore me out.
So we got up and we started out.
And I don't know, we was halfway from the entrance to the building to the pavement, sidewalk, when he said something about teaching.
I don't exactly know what.
Anyhow, I said, well, you know, I've often thought I'd like to teach.
He grabbed me by the arm and he almost shook me off my feet.
He says, you're just the man I'm looking for.
You're just the man I'm looking for.
He said, was $2,000 interest you?
Well, that was for 10 months' work, but $200 a month, which is more than I'd ever made anywhere in all my life up to that time.
So that was no problem.
The question was whether I really wanted to teach or not.
Anyhow, I went on home and talked to my father about it, and he wasn't too interested in that.
He was thinking about backing me financially in this
building profession, industry up in Northern Ohio, you see.
That was his hobby.
And he could visualize my doing that.
But I was truthful when I remarked to the dean that I had often thought that maybe I'd like to teach.
And he had just lost his man in the department in
who was teaching the sort of stuff for which I specifically had the experience with the Steel Corporation.
And that's what he meant when he says, I'm just the man you're looking for, that I'm looking for, just the man I'm looking for.
Well, I finally did accept and started teaching there.
And you were teaching what?
1st of September in 1920.
And you were teaching what?
In the Mechanical Engineering Department.
My major subjects were thermodynamics, heat power engineering, steam engines, steam boilers, and things like that.
How long did you stay teaching in class?
Oh, my goodness.
I had different assignments, different duties.
But I would say I always taught.
even though I was doing something else, research or something like that.
I never considered myself as being away from teaching from 1920 to 1946 at Lexington.
And then I had two years at the University of Michigan.
1946, 47, 48 and I came here in the fall of 48.
University of Michigan at where?
University of Michigan at Ann Arbor.
Okay, what were some of the changes that you saw at the University of Kentucky at
Well, you see, there was a depression.
First, there was a considerable expansion through the 20s, economic prosperity.
Then there was a stock market crash in 29.
Then there was depression through the 30s.
And then there was the World War.
For us, that was from, what, 41 to 45.
So a lot of things happened in that period.
When I started in there in 1920, the college professors ran everything.
We had a top administration, but they were just figureheads.
Their main job was looking after the finances and collecting fees and making up schedules, budgets, and so forth, and paying the proceeds out to the state.
We had a Senate, which consisted of all professorial ranks from assistant professor up, including the deans.
We had an assembly.
Well, first, that Senate met once a month.
Then there was an assembly, which included every employee of the university, which assembled once a semester.
That was mostly just a social gathering.
Then there was a committee of deans.
That wasn't the name they went by, but it consisted of all the deans of all the colleges, plus the business manager and the registrar and the president.
The president presided.
Then
There was the board, what we called board of trustees at that time, board of directors, other places.
And then the state legislature.
You had the state legislature, the board of directors, the... What you're saying is that this administrative bureaucracy took the power away from the college professors.
I'm telling you what the setup was.
State legislature, board of trustees,
the top echelon among the deans and administrators, the Senate, which included all of the faculty, assistant professor and above, and the Assembly, which included all employees of the college.
The business of the whole college was divided or split among those divisions of administration.
But the college professors themselves practically ran everything,
Nothing was ever done that wasn't approved by the Senate, which included assistant professors, associate professors, professors, heads of departments, and the deans.
It included the teaching personnel.
That changed drastically and dramatically during the Depression.
Because during the Depression, it was the finances that were important.
You didn't care about that so long as we had a job OK. And nobody cared whether we were teaching good or bad.
It was a question of having a job, holding a job.
So that the business of operating the university switched from education to the monetary aspects of getting enough money to pay the salaries of the people who ran the college.

So that meant that the responsibilities shifted from the lower ranks to the people at the top, particularly the board of directors, who had contact with the legislators and the politicians throughout the state and so forth and so on, who could supply the financial income that was needed.
So education per se dropped out of the picture.
And money became the important consideration.
Where were you going to get the money?
Did you get your advanced degree at the University of Kentucky at Lexington?
Well, I got my M.E.
degree there, yeah.
What year?
Well, there's a story about that.
If you were a member of the Senate, you could not be given a degree because you couldn't give a degree to yourself because the Senate gave degrees.
Since I started out as an assistant professor, went on to associate professor, professor, head of the department, and gotten that far by the middle 30s, I never had a chance to get a degree there.
I'd have to leave Kentucky and go someplace else.
But in the middle 30s,

The dean of agriculture and director of the Agriculture Experiment Station was trying to hire one of my men from under me to look after some of the mechanical engineering aspects of a new laboratory he was building for the Agriculture Department.
And this young man did not want to be transferred.
Well, I was a little bit unhappy with things at that time, middle of the Depression.
And in the meantime, my old boss, dean of engineering, had died.
And a new man had come in.
And I wasn't very happy.
So I learned that this young man didn't want to take this job.
I just thought came to me, well, by golly, I'm just going over there and apply for that job myself.
And I did that and I got it.
My salary was pretty good at that time.
I was head of the department and they couldn't pay me my current salary.
But the president of the university fixed that.
He said, well, that's easy.
We just divide his salary between agriculture and engineering.
So to make a long story short, I spent 10 years there from 1936 to 1946 as a research mechanical engineer in the College of Agriculture.
I went there to design this laboratory, which included a substantial investment in a lot of mechanical equipment.
And that took longer than we anticipated because we couldn't get some of the equipment that we needed, so that ran into the second year.
And then I got involved in some other mechanical phases of that department, and my duties there just grew and expanded so that I wound up spending ten years there.
And as I've said before, that it was in fact 10 of the most pleasant years of all my experience.
Why?
Just imagine yourself as being the one mechanical engineer among a group of all those agriculture specialists, both animal and vegetable.
And you were acting as a consultant to them.
And you had no competition.
You were the one.
And I'm telling you, it was a lot of fun, and I had a lot of pleasant experiences there, and I did a lot of work for them.
Now where was this?
This is in Lexington, Kentucky.
My work pertained chiefly to the tobacco industry, although that wasn't in all of it.
I designed two laboratories for spin metal work on the curing of tobacco.
data on what was happening to the tobacco going through different weather conditions.
I had a weather station which included outdoor temperatures, wet-bubble temperatures where I could get dew points and relative humidity, wind velocity, wind direction, and so forth.
I had almost a complete weather station.

which I devised myself, built some of the equipment, and I would, in the tobacco season in particular, curing season, I would keep these records and try to relate what was happening to the tobacco to the outside weather conditions.
So,

This change in position, although I really never stopped teaching, made it possible for me to suggest to the powers that be that since I was no longer a member of the Senate, I could get an advanced degree.
So I did that.
I wrote a dissertation, applied for a degree, and so forth,
It was concerned with this laboratory that I'd built and designed and built for them.
And I used it as the basis for the dissertation.
It was a description of an engineering job, which they accepted as being suitable for an engineering degree.
When did you marry?
Oh, that was back in 1922.
My wife and I started teaching at the University of Kentucky, but the same year.
What did she teach?
September of 1920.
Well, what did she teach?
First place, she graduated from Mount Holyoke College with a bachelor's degree.
That's in Massachusetts.
I don't know where you know where that is.
It's a women's college.
She spent four years there and got a bachelor's degree.
And then she went to Cornell University, got a master's degree.
And she was employed at the University of Kentucky in the fall of 1920 in the zoology department.
And her teaching specialty was histology and embryology, which worked that she had taken chiefly at Cornell.
And we belonged to a group of faculty there that socialized and had parties and so forth and so on.
We got acquainted.
And we married in 1922.
It was two years after we had started teaching.
Why did you decide?
I don't know whether you're interested in all this junk or not.
Just make it free.
You don't have to give all the time.
Well, it's a trouble.
It can't be free.
It's involved.
Back in the middle 20s, I needed some inflammatory assistance.
And I remember the former student.
who was excellent at writing laboratory reports.
I don't know if he was good at anything else or not.
When he turned in a laboratory report and I read it, he hit every point
